entry.title: Deploy on Jira
entry.summary: Jira, developed by Atlassian, is a popular project management and issue-tracking tool widely used by developers and teams to manage tasks, bugs, and agile workflows. For beginners, the easiest way to get started is by using Jira Cloud. Simply sign up on the Jira website, create a new project by choosing a suitable template like Scrum, Kanban, or bug tracking, and invite your team members. Jiraâ€™s interface is user-friendly, allowing you to set up boards with columns such as "To Do", "In Progress", and "Done" to track work visually. Itâ€™s beneficial for task management, where you can break down work into smaller issues, assign them to team members, and set due dates. Additionally, Jira excels in bug tracking, helping you log and prioritize software issues efficiently. If you're working with aâ€¦

entry.title: ## ðŸ§ Solving LeetCode Until I Become Top 1% â€” Day `5`
entry.summary:
ðŸ”¹ Problem: 909 Snakes and Ladders
Difficulty: #Medium Tags: #Matrix #BFS #Graph #BruteForce (in your own words)
Find the minimum number of moves to reach the last square of a Snakes and Ladders board, where each move can be from 1 to 6 squares forward. The board has snakes that send you back and ladders that take you forward. Brute Force Idea: This problem is actually a brute force problem, But in top of that we can use BFS to find the shortest path.
Optimized Strategy: We can use a BFS approach to explore all possible moves from the current position. Each position on the board can be treated as a node in a graph, and the edges represent valid moves (1 to 6 squares forward). We also need to account for snakes and ladders by mapping them to their respective destinations. We can use â€¦

entry.title: Beware the Shiny Tech Trap
entry.summary: It's 10:06 a.m. on a Tuesday. Planning is humming along. The teamâ€™s finally got some momentum, the roadmapâ€™s blessedly bug-free, and the last deploy didnâ€™t require a postmortem or whiskey. Then someone says it. â€œWhat if we rewrote the service in Rust?â€ You blink. Surely it was a joke. â€œItâ€™s just... with WASM and edge functions, we could simplify the whole architecture.â€ There it is. That soft, reverent tone. Like theyâ€™re reading scripture. Or pitching to YC. And just like that, weâ€™re off. Goodbye, roadmap. Hello, crowbrain. But youâ€™re not a crow. Itâ€™s an ill-timed rewrite that makes no sense even in context - like deciding to renovate your kitchen because the toasterâ€™s acting up on Christmas Day. Letâ€™s call it what it is: boredom. Or maybe not boredom exactly - impatience disguised as thouâ€¦

entry.title: # **How Poor Electricity and Expensive Internet Data Are Dissuading Young Nigerians from Joining the Tech Industry**
entry.summary:
The Nigerian tech industry has been on a promising rise, with startups like Flutterwave, Paystack, and Andela putting the country on the global map. However, despite this growth, many young Nigerians face significant barriers to entering the tech spaceâ€”chief among them being unstable electricity and expensive internet data. These challenges are more than just inconveniences; they actively discourage aspiring developers, designers, and tech enthusiasts from pursuing careers in technology. Hereâ€™s how: 1. Unstable Electricity: A Major Productivity Killer
Nigeriaâ€™s power supply is notoriously unreliable, with frequent blackouts and inconsistent voltage. For tech professionals and learners, this poses several problems: Disrupted Workflow: Coding, designing, or attending online classes râ€¦

entry.title: Shallow Copy & Deep Copy in Python (2)
entry.summary:
Buy Me a Coffeeâ˜• *Memos: My post explains the shallow and deep copy of a list. My post explains the shallow and deep copy of a dictionary. My post explains variable assignment. The variables which store the same tuple always have the same references.
Normal Copy:
*Memos: The one or more references of one or more tuples are stored in a variable. v1 and v2 have the same references of the same outer and inner tuple. is keyword can check if v1 and v2 have the same references.
##### Outer tuple #### # â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“â†“ â†“ v1 = ('a', 'b', ('c', 'd')) v2 = v1 # â†‘â†‘â†‘â†‘â†‘â†‘â†‘â†‘â†‘â†‘ # Inner tuple
print(v1) # ('a', 'b', ('c', 'd')) print(v2) # ('a', 'b', ('c', 'd')) print(v1 is v2, v1[2] is v2[2]) # True True
*Memos: copy() can be used for shallow copy. v1 aâ€¦

At the heart of every successful Agile team lies a unique role â€” the Scrum Master. But what exactly does a Scrum Master do, and why are they so essential? understanding of the Scrum Master and its roles in an Agile environment. What Is a Scrum Master? Facilitator of Scrum Events The Scrum Master is responsible for organizing and facilitating all the key Scrum ceremonies: â€¢ Daily Stand-ups (Daily Scrum): A quick check-in to discuss progress, roadblocks, and plans for the day. â€¢ Sprint Planning: Helping the team understand what can be delivered in the upcoming sprint and how it will be achieved. â€¢ Sprint Review: Guiding the team in showcasing compleâ€¦
